dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, you know, we've been looking at campaign finance, and, um, one thing that really jumps out is how much of the Trump campaign's money... seems to flow back into his own businesses.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, you know, we've been looking at campaign finance, and, um, one thing that really jumps out is how much of the Trump campaign's money... seems to flow back into his own businesses.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Trump moved additional campaign money to other businesses he owns, but 68% of the $2.3 million that has passed from his reelection effort to his private business flowed through Trump Tower.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, it's pretty wild. And the big one, of course, is Trump Tower, right? I mean, that place has been, like, central to his whole... identity, really.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, it's pretty wild. And the big one, of course, is Trump Tower, right? I mean, that place has been, like, central to his whole... identity, really.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Trump Tower has long played a starring role in Donald Trumps lifefirst as a brand-burnishing real estate project, then as the site of The Apprentice, more recently as a set for the 2016 presidential campaign.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Absolutely. From announcing his run in the atrium to, uh, campaign HQ upstairs. Even after he moved to the White House, the campaign, you know, just kept renting space there.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Absolutely. From announcing his run in the atrium to, uh, campaign H Q upstairs. Even after he moved to the White House, the campaign, you know, just kept renting space there.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: It was here, from the downstairs atrium, that Trump announced he was making a bid for the White House. Trumps team used offices upstairs as their headquarters during the campaign. ... His campaign kept its ties too, continuing to rent space from Trump Tower Commercial LLC.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Right, through his own company, Trump Tower Commercial LLC. And, um, federal filings show about $1.6 million of supporter money has gone to that property.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, through his own company, Trump Tower Commercial L L C. And, um, federal filings show about one point six million dollars of supporter money has gone to that property.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: He retained ownership of the property, through his 100% interest in an entity named Trump Tower Commercial LLC. ... And thus Trump, who has not yet donated anything to his own reelection campaign, managed to collect $1.6 million of supporter money through the property, according to a review of federal filings.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: [overlaps] And get this, 68% of all the campaign money that went to his *private* businesses, uh, flowed through Trump Tower. I mean, they say it's fair market rates, but...
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And get this, sixty eight percent of all the campaign money that went to his private businesses, uh, flowed through Trump Tower. I mean, they say it's fair market rates, but...
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Trump moved additional campaign money to other businesses he owns, but 68% of the $2.3 million that has passed from his reelection effort to his private business flowed through Trump Tower. ... The campaign has previously said it pays market rates in compliance with the law.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: But how would you even know, right? They won't say how much space they're renting. So it's, like, impossible to verify if it's, um, truly legit.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But how would you even know, right? They won't say how much space they're renting. So it's, like, impossible to verify if it's, um, truly legit.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Its hard to know if it truly is, however, because the campaign will not say how much space it is renting. Representatives for Trumps campaign and his business did not respond to requests for comment on Wednesday.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, exactly. And then there's the other stuff, like the $123,000 to Trump Restaurants LLC. For, you know, a little kiosk selling memorabilia in the Tower.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, exactly. And then there's the other stuff, like the one hundred twenty three thousand dollars to Trump Restaurants L L C. For, you know, a little kiosk selling memorabilia in the Tower.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Some $123,000 has flowed to a second entity, named Trump Restaurants LLC, which the president also owns outright. That company appears to be connected to a space in the lower level of Trump Tower, where the campaign has been selling memorabilia from a small kiosk, wedged between Trump Grill and a souvenir shop.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, the kiosk! That's the one where, uh, some experts said the $3,000 a month rent was appropriate, but then one guy looked at it and was like, 'That's robbery!'
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, the kiosk! That's the one where, uh, some experts said the three thousand dollars a month rent was appropriate, but then one guy looked at it and was like, 'That's robbery!'
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The campaign pays about $3,000 a month for that location, a figure that two real estate experts said seemed appropriate. A third, looking at the space from inside the building, concluded it was too much. Thats robbery, he said.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Right? Classic. And it's not just the Tower. His hotels have also seen some of that campaign cash. Like the Trump International Hotel in D.C.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right? Classic. And it's not just the Tower. His hotels have also seen some of that campaign cash. Like the Trump International Hotel in D C.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Trump Organization received smaller sums via the presidents hotel empire. In August, the Trump campaign spent at least $3,500 at the Trump International Hotel in Washington, D.C., just down Pennsylvania Avenue from the White House.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, the filings show, what, almost $4,500 just there in August? And overall, his hotels have collected, um, $231,000 from the campaign.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, the filings show, what, almost four thousand, five hundred dollars just there in August? And overall, his hotels have collected, um, two hundred thirty one thousand dollars from the campaign.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In August, the Trump campaign spent at least $3,500 at the Trump International Hotel in Washington, D.C., just down Pennsylvania Avenue from the White House. Federal filings show nearly $1,000 of additional money flowing into the Trump Hotel Collection. Trumps hotels have now collected $231,000 from his reelection campaign, according to an analysis of documents.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, you hear all these rumors, right? Like, he's gonna pump $100 million of his own money into the campaign, like he did somewhat in 2016.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, you hear all these rumors, right? Like, he's gonna pump one hundred million dollars of his own money into the campaign, like he did somewhat in twenty sixteen.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In early September, rumors surfaced that the president was considering investing as much as $100 million of his own money into his reelection campaign. He spent $66 million on his 2016 run.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: I mean, that seems... a little far-fetched, to be honest. He hasn't put in anything so far this cycle, and, uh, his cash on hand is estimated at $160 million.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: I mean, that seems... a little far-fetched, to be honest. He hasn't put in anything so far this cycle, and, uh, his cash on hand is estimated at one hundred sixty million dollars.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But given that he hasnt put in anything so far this cycle, and his portfolio only includes an estimated $160 million in cash, a $100 million donation seems far-fetched.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: [overlaps] He spent $66 million in 2016! So $100 million *now* when he hasn't put in a dime...
dialogue_turns.tts_text: He spent sixty six million dollars in twenty sixteen! So one hundred million dollars now when he hasn't put in a dime...
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: He spent $66 million on his 2016 run.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. Maybe, like, a $5 million donation? That would at least cover what his businesses have, uh, received from the campaign, you know?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. Maybe, like, a five million dollars donation? That would at least cover what his businesses have, uh, received from the campaign, you know?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: A gift of, say, $5 million might be more compatible with the presidents balance sheet. It probably wont move the needle much on his reelection chances, but at least it would cover the millions his businesses have received from the campaign.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Which, when you put it that way, really puts a different spin on, um, the whole 'self-funding' narrative.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which, when you put it that way, really puts a different spin on, um, the whole self-funding narrative.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: It really does. It's, uh, quite the business model, isn't it?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It really does. It's, uh, quite the business model, isn't it?
